dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REFINERY TOWN built around LAKE CALCASIEU; steel piping flaming exhaust, ugly beneath the tree-fringed sky--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A country ROADHOUSE. Gravel lot, no name on bar. Above th forest, the oil refineries pump smoke across sky-- Old CHEVY truck with camper and mudders rolls into lot, p Sits a beat as the driver, DEWALL, studies the tavern. He climbs out, big, bearded-- Enters the bar--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft in b.g., Waylon Jennings sings ‘BAKER STREET’ from a jukebox while a beefy BARTENDER cleans nozzles. Only othe inhabitants, RUST COHLE and GINGER at a gouged booth-- Dewall enters, nods to bartender, spots Cohle and Ginger- Bartender alert as Dewall lumbers to them-- He sits, stares, Cohle still in biker gear-- Ginger’s fac to shit, broken nose, two black eyes-- Dewall studies Gin

dialogues.speaker: DEWALL
dialogues.text: Happened your face?

dialogues.speaker: GINGER
dialogues.text: «+-Pool game the other night. Called the wrong dude on cheatin’.

dialogues.speaker: DEWALL
dialogues.text: ...Huh. (re Cohle) And what d’you want, again?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: .-.I’m repping some people, looking to get the good cook. They’d trade you or the IC Brotherhood, however you want it. Coke for crystal. All Dewall’s responses come after a pause of scrutiny--  "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 2.

dialogues.speaker: DEWALL
dialogues.text: Why ain’t I talkin to Miles?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Me an’ Ginger’re ole friends. Boosted together.

dialogues.speaker: DEWALL
dialogues.text: (to Ginger) You ain’t saying much.

dialogues.speaker: GINGER
dialogues.text: Figure I let my man give you details. Dewall watches them a while longer, jukebox throughout-- No answer,

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Shit I got coming in, you can step on it five, six times, it’s still kick. Just means you cook a little more. For a lot more profit. not a hint of anything but a reptile intelligence--

dialogues.speaker: DEWALL
dialogues.text: Ain’t got no use for it. Or your money.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Money don’t spend?

dialogues.speaker: DEWALL
dialogues.text: ...I can see your soul at the edges of your eyes. It’s corrosive, like acid. You got a demon, little man. (rises) And I don’t like your face. It makes me want to do things to it. Dewall nods to Bartender, who nods back--

dialogues.speaker: DEWALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You call me again, Ginger, I’m settin Miles on you... (to Cohle) I see you again, I’m puttin you down. There’s a shadow on you, son. He walks out. Cohle turns to Ginger, pissed--  "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 3.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: “Called the wrong dude on cheatin’”? You think I’m stupid as you? He’s right, you know... With only his eyes, Cohle threatens Ginger’s life--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...You wanna see my shadow? INT. MOVING, COHLE’S TRUCK - DAY 4 Cohle drives. Ginger not visible, but audible, whining-- juiced from the past 24 hours, sweating. He’s on a CB RAD

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You got him, Marty? You fucking better, the shit I’ve-- INT. MOVING, HART’S CAR - DAY 5 Hart drives, also on CB RADIO-- Down a rural highway, cut away from the refineries, into deep woods--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: --I do. I got him. But we’re on empty roads now. I gotta drop back or he’1l spot the tail... AHEAD, Dewall’s truck is small in the distance-- No other Forest fences the road, distant refineries--

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’s Ginger?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wrapped up. Tell me your location--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: South of I-10, along the Creole Nature Trail. Going toward Carlyss. Hurry up, man-- INT. MOVING, COHLE’S TRUCK - DAY 6 Cohle hangs up the CB. Speeds, zigging through traffic--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: How we doing back there, Ginger? PAN as he talks, to extended cab behind front seat-- Wher Ginger has been duct-taped up in several garbage bags, struggles in vain as Cohle’s driving slams him around the  "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 4. I/E. HART’S CAR - BACK ROADS - CARLYSS, LA - DAY 7 Hart following at a long distance, on an exposed country A slight RISE-- and Hart loses Dewall’s truck-- He can no longer spot the Chevy he’s following-- FUCK--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart stands at his CAR, parked on a dirt shoulder beside forest as Cohle’s truck arrives, parks-- He exits--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Where's Ginger?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Kicking back in a ditch. What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Lost him a minute. I had to double-back a few times till I saw a turn off-- He nods toward the forest, to a path so thin and grassy i almost indistinguishable from the woods--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Did you lose him?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Found his truck. Parked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart and Cohle walk the thin path, badges and guns visibl THICK FOREST surrounds-— They stop as the trail tapers off-- Where a rusted CATTLE fences off a small CLEARING-- Beyond the cattle-gate sits Dewall’s CHEVY. DEEP WOODS surround a wilderness maze--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ...We gotta call it in, Rust.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ...We don’t know where they are yet... Just maybe about where they are. I don’t wanna flood the woods. How many directions could they run? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 5.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Parish? Who says they won't get a tip-off?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: We're not gonna find em from here.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: .---Cut sign, man. You ever been hunting?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: 10-point buck, year before last. Sixty yards.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Real hunting. Tracking. Not waiting to ambush a deer sniffing gash bait. Hart looks to the thick forest, endless possibilities for ambush-- He turns back to Rust--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Jesus, you're a prick. ...We find the place, we come back. Call it in. One of us’ll stay on surveillance.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I can live with that. They look at each other a moment, an acknowledgment, the increasing stakes of their reliance on one another-- Cohle steps over the gate, Hart following, until they’re swallowed--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 52--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: So you get a tip where Ledoux cooks. Cohle comes back... from wherever he was...

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: .--You knew it was gonna get here, man. Just the once... The way you tell it.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I tell it the same way I told it to the shooting board and every cop bar between Houston and Biloxi... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11 12 13 14 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 6.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know why the story’s exactly the same, seventeen years gone? Because it only went down the one way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle and Hart, dirty, moving through FOREST, no clear pa discernible-- Cohle leads in a crouch, scanning--

dialogues.speaker: HART 2012, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cohle’s dad taught him bow-hunting. Had to track game till you got within maybe thirty yards of it-- Cohle spots broken stalks-- He indicates the path to Hart continues in that direction--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON a monofilament TRIPWIRE across a pathless bramble-- Co follows the LINE, which leads to a CLAYMORE at the base o tree, covered in leaves, ‘Front Toward Enemy'-- Rust carefully leads them over the TRIPWIRE, deeper in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same wilderness, another TRIPWIRE Cohle spots, another on overhead, cross-hatched to CLAYMORES-- They see-- TWO STICK LATTICEWORKS mark the path beyond, small sentin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rust Cohle, 49, sips his flask. Sets it down. He arranges army of beer-can men, toying--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ...-It’s a really good story. I never get tired of tellin it. Legend shit, you know?

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: Why you so hot to see the new discovery file, man? A quick, admonishing glance from Gilbough to Papania- Shu Back to Cohle, who clocked that--  15 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 7.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ...-Well, why you so hot to not let me see it? This is like a consultation, huh?

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: .»-You go first. You take me through it, I’1ll let you see what we got. Long beat, lights a cig-- Exhales a slow thick plume--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I’1l hold you to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Familiar view of Ledoux’s METH SHACK: TRACK UP a hillock dim sound- Thunk, Thunk -reaching the top of the rise-- Cohle and Hart both crest the hillock. Sweaty, shirts soa They take in the clearing, the shack, back to one another They draw guns and they begin their descent-- FOLLOW, halting, crouching in tall grass for cover-- Peer around to study the shack, the shed. Stick latticeworks a arranged around the cabin-- Detectives speak in whispers-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Tripwires back there. Clearing could be mined...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Alright. How you wanna do it?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: «+-Go back. Call it in. I’11 wait here. Hart given pause by Cohle’s obvious calculations--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: «+-You gonna hold position?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You bet. Hart understands that he has no intention of waiting-- Then, down in the clearing, they both see-- DEWALL exits cabin, lumbers toward the SHED near the treeline--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: »--Go on now, Marty.  16 17 18 19 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 8. Hart knows he can leave Cohle or he can back him up--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ..-Fuck you. Gonna do that without me... This means something to Cohle-- He motions that he’ll go

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ..-Match my footprints. Cohle starts down the last dozen yards before the treelin breaks-- Hart follows--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rust Cohle, 49--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: We were just about to turn back and call in Parish, State, whoever... I mean, we're ready to just leave the shit be. Wasn't what happened. Soon as we'd decided to back off-- He claps his hands together- whack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 52--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: --Blam! Bullets cut through, right by Rust’s head. We both roll opposite ways, into high growth. But we’re spotted. They got something high velocity. Blew apart a tree between us. I mean, it is on--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No such conflict. Rust leads them out of the treeline, in clearing-- He stays in shadow, studying the ground-- COHLE’S POV-- small indentations in the wide lawn, where dandelions grow (indicates disturbed earth): mines-- Cohle crosses the open ground quickly, zig-zags dandelion patches-- Ends by crouching beside the CABIN, beneath a w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle, 49, over-dramatic--  20 21 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 9.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Under fire-- Ferns and whatnot bursting around us. Later found out they had an AK. With the drum cartridge. Cut a swathe right through the forest-- choomchoomchoom. Heavy fire--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle’s safe against the cabin, beneath the window. Moves the other side, out of sight of the SHED--

dialogues.speaker: HART 2012, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Blamblamblam. Felt them AK rounds zip by, even with the ringing in my ears-- Whif.Whif.Whif. Hart's followed Cohle down. Now goes a little farther, cr at the back of the main cabin-- LATTICEWORKS posted aroun various sizes, recalling the initial crime scene-- ON COHLE, peeping up through a crack in a foil-covered wi nothing. Sticking his head around the trailer, to the SHE movement. Sudden creaks from the TRAILER, it shakes with footsteps, rocking as something heavy moves inside-- Hart indicates the other side of the trailer, a head-nod- Cohle moves to that side of the trailer-- Hart double-checks the SHED. No movement-- Cohle crouches below another window, near the door-- He p through and sights in on the interior, aiming his pistol- signals for Hart to enter through front door--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE LEDOUX stands at a sink, rinsing out what look lik old dog dish. Tattooed, he wears only a towel wrapped aro his waist-- The small kitchen filthy, full of dirty dishe chemistry equipment, hot-plates-- A spiral brand on his b Outside the window, unseen, Cohle has Ledoux in his sight The running water masks the slight squeal of the screen d HART stands in the front door, gun level on the big man’s

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: State Police. Put your hands on top your head. Lace your fingers and get on your knees. Do it.  22 23 24 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 10. Reggie considers making a move, maybe grabbing the RIFLE sink-- Cohle whistles to him through the window-- Reggie second man with a gun on him-- Slowly he raises his hands, locks his fingers atop his he Flat, belligerent stare, as if he’s in control-- Hart bac

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on out here now. Get down on your knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie descends trailer steps, Hart with gun on him. Cohl comes around from the side, covering him while watching t SHED for signs of movement-- Reggie kneels down, stares between the detectives-- Hart his hands behind his back-- Then Reggie looks at the LATT STICKS positioned around the yard-- their shadows--

dialogues.speaker: LEDOUX
dialogues.text: ..-It’s time, isn’t it? The black stars. A muffled THUMP sounds from the back of the TRAILER-- Coh Hart exchange glances-- Hart gestures that he’ll look in. Cohle moves between Led and the SHED, watching both as-- Hart enters the trailer-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 35, testifies across a long table to members of the police SHOOTING BOARD, telling the same story as in 2012-

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: They’d spotted us before we crossed the forest, see? So all we could do was duck for cover, dig in and try gettin close... It was chaos.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINER 1
dialogues.text: .+-How did you proceed?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Rust rolled off in the high grass. He made a run to the back of the trailer. I was pinned behind a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle holds his gun on Ledoux, studies him--  25 26 27 28 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 11.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ...Why the antlers?

dialogues.speaker: LEDOUX
dialogues.text: .-.I saw you in my dream. You’re a priest, too... I know what happens next. He nods to the stick latticeworks surrounding, their shad seem to elongate across the ground as clouds pass--

dialogues.speaker: LEDOUX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're in Carcosa now. With me. He sees you... Cohle tweaks to ‘Carcosa’, from Charlie’s speech--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart moves furtively through the trailer, gun drawn-- Dar filthy. He passes an AK with drum barrel, turns corner-- Clears room... Turns into hallway-- He reaches a DOOR at end. Its outside is pad-locked-- Listens--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle watches Ledoux as-- The SHED DOOR opens, Dewall exi carrying a bin of chemistry supplies-- He catches the sce

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Right there! Don’t move! Stay right there and get on your knees! State police!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear Cohle in b.g. as Hart smashes off the outer hinge wh the padlock connects-- Opens door onto a dark room, dark, smell hitting him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle covers Dewall, who stands frozen near the treeline- Ledoux still kneels, cuffed--

dialogues.speaker: LEDOUX
dialogues.text: You'll do this again. Time is a flat circle.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: What’s that, Nietzche? Shut the fuck up.  29 30 31 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 12. The trailer’s door slams open and Hart stomps out, walks directly to Ledoux and BANG-- Executes him with a head-sh He stands over the fallen body in blind, twitching rage, head smeared across the grass-- Cohle is shocked, looks at Marty, Ledoux’s body-- Cohle swiftly turns back to Dewall, who witnessed-- Witho knowing why Hart did that, Cohle is prepared to back him raises his gun, aims for Dewall’s head: They have to do t now-— Realizing his intent, Dewall drops the supplies and takes running, his big, loping body absurd-- Hart watches as-- Cohle tracks Dewall easily, about to ta kill-shot, when-- An old bouncing betty springs up. KA-BOOM-- Dewall explod Cohle and Hart flat on the ground as dirt and debris rain latticework sticks are all still standing. A vantage migh suggest an observational quality in them--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 52--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I'd come around behind, took out Ledoux, and the other ole boy made a run for it. Guess he wasn’t thinking about where they’d put them mines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle and Hart rise as dust settles-- Ledoux’s body betwe them, Cohle looks at Marty, wtf?-- Cohle thinks about it-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: (re Ledoux) Get those cuffs off him before the blood settles. We gotta make this look right. Cohle enters the trailer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle walks down the dark hallway, toward the closet with broken padlock-- Approaches it-- Cohle’s face twists in r  32 33 34 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 13. He sees what Marty saw: Their forms partially obscured by shadow, TWO CHILDREN’S LEGS are visible, bruised, shackle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rust Cohle, 49--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Captain America, Marty Hart, he flanks around behind Ledoux. And just as he’s turning- Bam. Clean shot. Put him down. His buddy made a run for it. And their cracker-ass security system did the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle exits, furious, carrying the AK-- Hart with Ledoux’ body, uncuffed, in shock over what he did--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: «-.Oh fuck...

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Come on. We have to hurry. See to the kids. Don’t let em out here till I say so. Hart looks at him, seeing his future vanish. Never killed man before... Cohle sees this--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? Him? Fuck that. Good for you, Marty. Cohle moves near the body, stands over it as he aims the toward the woods--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice to see you commit to something. Cohle opens fire on the woods from where they approached-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Cohle, 32, testifies before the shooting board--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: -+.-Got lucky, all it was. We coulda just as easily been chewed to pieces by that AK...  35 36 37 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW MOTION ON Cohle firing AK with barrel drum, shooting into the woods--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE 1995, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...-Myself? In all honesty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Rust and the shooting board--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I can tell you I have walked away from the experience with an even greater respect for the sanctity of human life. Glances sideways- ‘anybody buy that?’--

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINER 2
dialogues.text: Thank you, Detective. And I believe I speak for the board when I commend you on the heroism displayed by you and Detective Hart. Cohle meekly waves off the compliment, humble--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Cohle and Hart had left their vehicles parked, now STATE PD CRUISERS, lights flashing, AMBULANCES. MEDICS an PATROLMEN standing around, a REPORTER waiting as-- ON WOODS-- Martin Hart and Rust Cohle emerge side-by-side of them carrying a CHILD covered in a ratty blanket-- Hart carries a little girl, her eyes closed, face dirty-- We don’t know the gender of Cohle’s, because the blanket covers the child’s face-- Only see the small feet-- As the medics and patrolmen rush to their aid, a news REP takes a picture-- FADE TO WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: 38 39 40 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 15.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE 2012, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There were the twig sculptures. And LSD they had on hand matched the batch in Dora Lange. Everybody was pretty satisfied we’d gotten our man... A week later, after the shooting board. Hart and Cohle en homicide to applause-- Copies everywhere of THE LAFAYETTE ADVERTISER, front page pictures of Cohle and Hart carryin the children. Headline: ‘Hero Detectives Stop Killers, Sa Girl ’--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other detectives shake hands with Cohle and Hart. A victory for the whole team--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE 2012, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Boy’d gone missing in January. He'd been dead less than a day. The girl hadn’t been reported yet. Came from St. Landry. She was catatonic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle, 49, no pleasure in recalling ‘the victory’ now--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I checked on her, some years later. In assisted living for girls with special needs. Cohle thinks on that event, hits the flask--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...Why should I live in history? I don’t want to know anything anymore. This is a world where nothing is solved. Somebody once told me, ‘Time is a flat circle.’ ...-Everything we’ve ever done or will do, we’re gonna do over and over again... And that little girl and that little boy are gonna be in that room again and again, forever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Hart, 52-- Tired after being pulled into these memories, but still in them--  4l 42 43 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 16.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: There’s a few news stories about us, you wanted to find them. I got promoted to detective sergeant. Rust got a commendation for bravery. Basically because I insisted. And, uh... Things were real good, I guess, for a while. Rust even chilled out, got more regular... Maggie came around. After a lot of talking. Counseling. Getting in a shootout kinda opened her up to forgiveness. Or the possibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKATING RINK. Hart skating with Macie and Audrey-- Maggie skates too, left back by the girls wanting to both hold t father’s hands-- MAGGIE’S POV as Hart skates through stage-fog and laser- lights with the girls, one holding each hand--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macie eyes stuffed-toys through the glass wall of a GRABB CRANE MACHINE-- She watches Hart steer the claw, set it o large stuffed TOY-- Audrey already has a stuffed toy and Macie watches with anxiety-- The claw raises and lifts the toy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie meets them as they exit, Hart carrying the toys as girls skate out the arcade--

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Go take off your skates. It’s time to go. They both protest and beg for more time-- ‘Please, please

dialogues.speaker: MACIE
dialogues.text: Is Daddy coming home yet?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: -..One more time around. Then take them off, okay?  "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 17. The girls rush to get in their last skate on the rink, leaving Hart and Maggie alone, stuffed toys under his arm

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Thank you. I needed this. I think they did, too... Beat, some kind of inner Rubicon approached in her--

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: ...Were there others?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ...What?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Besides her. Were there others?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: No. No. And- Listen, that was a different person, Maggie. I lost it. Just for a little- I’m back. I’m begging. I'll keep begging. I‘ll go to my grave begging. She looks him in the eye, poker-faced-- Looks away--

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s not just the... affair. You used to be a good man. You used to pay attention...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Mag, I almost died. I cut the booze. Five weeks now. Started doing this program, Promise Keepers--—

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: «+-You got a long road to climb.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Yes I do. She scrutinizes him-- Having removed skates, Audrey and Macie run to their side They take their toys from Marty, who crouches, kisses the

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Are you coming home?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: .--Not tonight.  44 45 46 47 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 18. He hugs them, humble, deferential to Maggie--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Hart, 52, remembering things he’s tried not to thi about--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Few years. Good ones...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.1996, Macie chases Audrey through the yard. Audrey has sister’s tiara, teasing her-- Before Macie can catch her, Audrey throws the tiara up in tree, where it hangs on a branch-- Macie chases her off screen-- STAY ON little girl’s TIARA, hung up on a tree branch-- MONTAGE SCENE with--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart's affected, remembering his daughters-- Almost to se

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ...Do you know the good years, when you're in ‘em? Or do you just wait for ‘em, till one day you get ass-— cancer and realize the good years came and went? ...Because there’s a feeling. You might notice it sometime. A feeling like life slipped through your fingers. Like the future is behind you. Like it was always behind you... (beat) I cleaned up, but... Maybe I didn’t change. Not the way I needed to... ...-You remember what I said, The Detective’s Curse? ...The solution to my whole life was under my nose. That woman. Those girls. And I was watching everything else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON the little girl’s TIARA, 2002, six years later-- Never taken down, now molded, rotting, branches grown through i  48 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 19. BELOW, MACIE (now 13) and AUDREY (now 16) walk from the b stop and into their home. Not talking, Macie texting-- Bo oblivious to the tiara hanging above--

dialogues.speaker: HART 2012, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: See, infidelity is one kind of sin... But my true failure was inattention... I understand that now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About eighty MEN in a multi-purpose hall, all white, midd age, like a Kiwanis meeting-- SIGNS on wall and at front proclaim ‘PROMISE KEEPERS ‘99: TOWARD THE MILLENNIUM’ -- SPEAKER at the front of room with podium-- Seated behind speaker is BILLY LEE TUTTLE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Hart sits in back row, bored, holding a PK PAMPHLE which reads ‘Male Virility: The Holy Spirit of Creation’- Chuckles at pamphlet (which presents the male sex drive a aspect of the Holy Spirit which must be fed)-- To GUY bes him--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You read this?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (earnest) Yeah. I gave one to my wife.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: As we stand on the cusp of our first decade, we couldn’t be more happy or fortunate to have as special guest speaker one of the spiritual guideposts of our great state. Billy Lee Tuttle's ministries have touched generations, and he’s here to talk about our roles as Men of Jesus in the 21st Century... APPLAUSE as Billy Lee Tuttle rises, takes podium--

dialogues.speaker: TUTTLE
dialogues.text: I’m real pleased to be here speaking with you... Muscular, Christian men. I see a Renaissance here before me. Men firm of resolve. Firm of heart. Firm of hand. A type we don’t see enough in this day and age.  49 50
Amens, nods-- ON Hart, rolling his eyes, checking his wat ON the pamphlet in his hand, a drawing of a biblical EVE, with the caption “And she was_made to be a companion

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hurture and serve him"-- He looks up and Tuttle meets his eyes--

dialogues.speaker: TUTTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Men with strength to prove righteous in faithless times. ...Traditional husbands. ...Traditional wives. Marty rises, walks out of the meeting--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 52, lost in thought--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: ..-How’d Detective Cohle sort of, chill out, like you say?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Started talking to people, for one. Down the line, one of those set-ups Maggie was so intent on finally hit. A doctor, no less. She and Rust had a thing, few years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 50 ON a table at a nice country RESTAURANT, soul food, famil style. Hart, Maggie, Rust and LAURIE PERKINS (35), pretty refined-- Hart drinks water, no booze on the table--

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (re Rust) .--No, he’s a lot more right than he sounds. Serotonin. Endorphins. Cortisol. Dopamine. It’s more like a biological computer than we talk about.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Great. Now there’s two of you. It’s all genial, relaxed-- Hart and Maggie are close agai

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: No, I’m not really like him. I like bright colors. The Three Stooges.  51 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 21.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I’m into the Marx Brothers. And I dig on a good sunrise.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: But not sunsets.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: They're the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: It’s really not.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Laurie--?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I give him little things like that. He’s conflict-oriented, so when I deny him small arguments, it builds up his energy.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Boy, are you ever a match for this dude. Chuckles, but the observation causes a muted disquiet in does Laurie grabbing his wrist affectionately-- He smiles Hart clocks the smile’s tension, recognizes its familiari band starts apart from the small dance floor, country-wal

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Maggie) Come dance with me. Maggie rises and he leads her out, Cohle and Laurie watch Cohle glances to Laurie, grins, somehow forced--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 52--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Look. You know about Rust. During those seven years, he probably pulled more assists than any detective in the State. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 53 54 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 22.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It started getting around real fast, between city and sheriff’s-- You need a confession, see if State Detective Cohle’s available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle, 49-- Gilbough appealing to vanity, without being o

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: Your interview technique. Sure there’s no secret you could pass along? A magic question, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Look... Everybody knows there's something wrong with them. They just don’t know what it is. Everybody wants confession. Everybody’s got an empty space. An absence. Now, no matter how they try filling it- maybe you're a juicehead, a gash hound, a fat lady eats every time she feels something -it’'s the same vacant space. And that is the silence of God. And it doesn’t go away. Everybody wants a cathartic narrative for it. The guilty especially. And everybody's guilty... You know that. INT. LAURIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 53 Living room of Laurie’s house, as she and Cohle sit on th couch, bathed in the light of the television-- She’s curl against his side-- Cohle drinking a beer-- His face is somewhat tense, introverted-- Laurie watches television, some innocuous reality TV-- Cohle looks at th her hair, the television, the walls-- He seems like a man being slowly, quietly tortured by his surroundings--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart sits at table eating with his family. Maggie (39) serves. Macie is 13, bubbly, girly, and Audrey, 16, dress grungy, frowns at her food-- WALL CALENDAR - 2002--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I’m just trying to understand, babe... I mean, what’re you going for, here? What’s the message?  "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 23.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: There is no message. It’s just me.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What’s you? Your clothes? Your hair? I mean, I look at Macie, and--

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Women don’t have to look like you want them to.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I agree. I’m not talking about ‘women,’ I’m talking about my teenage daughter, and I’m not telling you what to wear. I’m just doing my best to understand...

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Who told you you had to understand? Why would you? Hart ducks it; knows she has his number-- Turns to Macie Maggie enters, sits--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (to Macie) Mom said you made cheerleader?

dialogues.speaker: MACIE
dialogues.text: There were like, ten girls who didn’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: They have eighth-grade cheerleaders?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Same way there’s football players.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: (re potatoes, Macie) Why’re you taking more? You’re just gonna throw them up.

dialogues.speaker: MACIE
dialogues.text: Shut up. Why don’t you go blow a basketball player, suicide girl?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Macie!-- Apologize!

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: --What the hell does that mean?  "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 24. Looking between the girls, who glance at one another, the face down, pick at their food in a shrinking, demure way prohibits his pressing the matter-- But he is enraged--

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Audrey) What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Let it go. Dinner’s not the time for you to suddenly get particular.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I’'m- What? I am the Man of this family. My-my daughter makes a comment like that- I’m-

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: .»..-You’re as dramatic as them. Drop it, Marty.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What’s it mean?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: --Why don’t you ask her what I meant? Huh? It means my sister's a bitch, that’s all. The girls answer his lead, but the level of emotion and confrontation is too much for Marty-- He flips stances--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ...-The hell? Christ, can’t we just have dinner? Your mom made us a nice meal, we- we’re not supposed to be like this-- No one buys his sentimental platitudes, since his actions embody them-- The girls stay silent--

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: ...-You have to be the way you want your children to behave. Girls see the exchange, watch-- He doesn’t reply-- Everyo picks at their food, silverware against china--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ...Hear your grades are good.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: That’s because school’s a joke.  55 56 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 25.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ...-Terrific. Great news. He rises abruptly, takes his plate into the living room-- The women stay at the table-- SOUND of TV turning on--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 52--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Rust’s girl, uh, Laurie. She became, like, Chief of something, Lafayette General. I think.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: You know what happened there? Between them.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What always happens between men and women... Reality. (beat) My understanding, from Maggie. They wanted different things. You’d have to ask him.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: .+.-When do you think things started to, how you put it, change again, with Detective Cohle?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ..-Maybe, early on in 2002. But it was his life. Mine was steady. Like I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle, 49-- Gilbough listening closely--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Years... “Time is a flat circle.” You know anything about M-brane theory, detectives? Papania rolls eyes-- Gilbough shakes his head slowly-- Co uses a beer can to illustrate, tracing the can’s surface, beyond it--  57 58

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s like, in this universe, our consciousness has to process time linearly, forward. But outside our spacetime, from what would be a fourth-dimensional perspective, time wouldn’t exist. And from that vantage, could we attain it, we’d see-- A sudden display of strength: between two hands, Cohle crushes the can to a flat disc--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our spacetime would look flattened, like a single sculpture, with matter in a superposition of every place it ever occupied. Our sentience just cycles through our lives like carts on a track. He lights a cigarette, idly arranges the beer-can men it’s now four surrounding one, holds up the flat disc

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everything outside our dimension, see, that’s eternity. Eternity, looking down at us. To us, it’s a sphere. To them, it’s a circle. He twists the disc slowly in front his eyes-- Beat--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: Mr. Cohle... What happened in 2002? Cohle’s eyes lock with his--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO PD DETECTIVES and SERGEANT observe Cohle working a suspect through windows into an INTERVIEW ROOM--—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle, 39, paces slowly around GUY FRANCIS, 42, a long 3 26. so that can-— 57 58 , vangy man with an opaque glass eye. Cohle holds a thick file on Fra leafing through the case--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: They think you’re the drug store robber, Francis. Killed two people in Livingston. Call you ‘The Southern-Fried Pharmacy Firearms Fiend.’  "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 27.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: ..-No, sir. Cohle studies him-- Francis doesn’t say anything, sweats-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Stuff they got now, man. Fingerprints. DNA. You'd have to be some kinda genius to get around all that. (leans in) And you ain’t no kinda genius, are you? Best play for you, plead impairment. You know what that means? Means you can’t be held accountable for your actions.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: -.-I don’t think I should be blamed, entirely, I mean. What I done under the influence of anything.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I’m not saying you should be either. Shit, man. PCP, one time, famous case. Guy cut off his own face.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: ...F’real?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. That and meth? If that ain’t an insanity defense, I don’t know what is. I mean, how they gonna call a man not on anything insane, he does something crazy. But a man’s on something makes him crazy, that’s sane? Works both ways.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: ...Yeah... Exactly. I mean, I’m not even saying I remember. I was so shit-hammered...

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: .-.I’d take that play. Insanity defense... But the amnesia thing won't help. See, cause you sobered up. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So now, you being in your right mind- best way for you to show the difference between that man and this one, is to show shock. Terror and remorse... This ‘I can’t remember’ shit. You gotta do better. You gotta let ‘em clear the case, show shame, penitence...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: .--I am. I do. I’m scared, sir...

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Hhn. You remember what you told the pharmacist?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: .-."Give me everything”...

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: There you go. And you’re sorry, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah... I’m ill...

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You see what you just did? You just copped to a double murder. They got you now. Guy stiffens, thinks like a trapped animal and abruptly m a decision, leans close to Cohle, as though in confidence

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I wanna deal. I know things.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Like, I know who you are. That woman in the woods, way back. The antlers. Cohle’s eyes widen, piqued--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: That don’t mean nothing. That was in the papers. You ain’t got shit.  59 60 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 29.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: «+-You- You all n-never got him. Man that did that. He’s been out there. Killing.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Ain't nobody did that killing’s still alive, boy. And you don’t know fuck-all about anything.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: .-.-I met him once. There’s big people, know about him. But I wanna deal.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You spilling shit boy--

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Deal with me for them murders... I tell you about The Yellow King. Name triggers-- Cohle backhands Francis, yanks him by the collar--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Gimme a name. Give me a fucking name!!! Cohle slams him into the wall, pressing his windpipe--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUTSIDE - FOLLOW the two PD with their SERGEANT, as all r into the interview room as-- NOTICE a PATROLMAN (CHILDRESS) hangs back in the hall, ha heard the conversation--

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: IwannadealI wanna deal! The Yellow King! You deal with me!

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: What’re you saying, huh? What're you on about? Givemeaname-- The two Detectives pull Cohle off of Francis-- Sergeant s the suspect down-- PD tugs Cohle out--  "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 30.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: You got the confession, then you made it inadmissable--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: What’re you doing? He’s still talking--

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE 2
dialogues.text: We don’t treat our suspects like that here--

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE 1
dialogues.text: He’s shucking and jiving you, Detective. He knows who you are.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You called me in-- (calms ) .--Hold on. Hold on, I want to talk to him--

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE 2
dialogues.text: We'll let you know, we need anything else.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: You can visit the prisoner when you calm down, request further interview. We appreciate the assist.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE 1
dialogues.text: Come on-- TWO PATROLMEN pass by to take Francis to holding-- One of them is Childress, who heard the conversation-—

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: What’s going on here?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: We gotta salvage a double-murder confession, is what's going on. If he wasn’t just running you, you’1l get anything we get... You have my word. Cohle’s frustrated, mind spinning with what Francis said- clocks the other detectives, shakes the Sergeant’s hand--  62 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 31.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I’ll be back. Tomorrow. Walks out-- Into-- INT. LAURIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Cohle walking from the dining area to kitchen with hand, fleeing a conversation behind him, as he and clean up after dinner--

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: .-.I’m not saying we have to decide now. It’s just a subject... They meet in the KITCHEN, Cohle sets plates down--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I’m saying. As a subject. I closed that for myself.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: ...Baby, I know how you feel. Because of what happened. I do.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ...It’s not that.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Of course it is, no matter what you say. And I’m saying. There might be a kind of healing in this for you.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: There’s nothing to heal, Laurie... It's a philosophical decision. 62 dishes in Laurie She calls him out, blocking his exit from the kitchen--

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Bullshit. If you're going to live... being so honest. Without illusion, you said. Then you can’t be serious. If you really think the reason you don’t want children is philosophical, you are a- a blind man describing an elephant...

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ...It’s wrong. That’s how I feel.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: «..-You’re scared... Or... (beat, hurt) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...Is it you don’t-- with me? ...-You don’t love me that way? He freezes a half-second too long-- He wants to be a good but that word still registers a suspicious abstraction--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: No. It’s not about you. I wouldn’t have children with anyone, Laurie. I'm sorry... He passes her, enters the living room, where something catches his eye... He pauses beside a shelf, looks at it, Laurie stands in kitchen doorway-- COHLE POV -- he stares at the framed Lafayette Advertiser PHOTO of him and Hart, the ‘Hero Cops’ headline-- His own face in the glass, seven years later--

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: ...A seven-year old picture’s more important than this discussion? (beat) You've got such good eyes for detail, Rust. The seams in everything and all the cracks. But you miss a shit-ton of what's obvious.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ...What’ve I missed?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: How did you think this would sit with me? You heard me talk about it... Did you think I would just be content to erase any hopes for that area of my life? For being a mother? Without really looking at her--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ...No. I guess I never expected you to do that. Hurts her, that he’d allowed his intentions’ misinterpretation--

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: ..-Are you just-- I don’t know if you're mostly good, and just a coward. Or if you’re an asshole, and just a little smarter than most.  "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 33.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: .-.I’d hate to call that one. She walks out, and he turns--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-I’m sorry, Laurie... He means it, but his mind is almost entirely elsewhere. B to his reflection over the framed newspaper-- The PHOTO-- 63 INT. HART’S CAR - NIGHT 63 Late night. Martin Hart parked at home with Audrey in the car. SILENCE-- Audrey’s lipstick and makeup is badly smea ashamed and Marty drives, furious--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Tell it to your mother. He glances at her with raw hate that makes her wither wit its disgust-- They get out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her robe and nightgown, Maggie is waiting in the foyer Marty and Audrey enter-- Maggie was also awoken from slee and has been waiting for Hart and Audrey to come home--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Deputy found her parked in a car. With two boys.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Audrey) What?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: In states of undress... You know, like fucking. Audrey shrinks, as Maggie looks at her shocked and maybe horrified--

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boys were nineteen and twenty. Got ‘em in holding for the night. I haven't decided whether to press statch rape charges.  65 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 34.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: What? You can’t--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I can do anything I goddamn want to those boys. Think about that.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Audrey. My God. Look at me. Look at me. What are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ‘Thinking?’ What the fuck is wrong with you? Or is this one of those things I’1l never understand. You bein captain of the varsity slut team-—

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: ...Fuck you! He slaps her-- She runs to her room-- He’s instantly asha of the act, frozen with fear, guilt-- Maggie’s aghast... follows Audrey--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MACIE (14), watches from a crack in her door as Audrey st by in tears, hitting Macie’s door--

dialogues.speaker: MACIE
dialogues.text: Ow! Maggie following behind as Audrey’s door slams, locks--

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Macie) Go to bed. This isn’t to do with you. Macie smirks to herself, into her PHONE, ‘My slut sister’ She shuts her door as her mother knocks on Audrey’s--

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-Audrey. Open up. It’s just you and me. You need to talk about this. No answer-- Maggie’s POV, turning back down a dark hallwa closed doors, a band of light underneath them--  66 67 68 69 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty hasn’t moved, looks at his hands, guilt-ridden-- Th to save himself, through some inner rationale, he convert that guilt into righteousness-- He’s the wronged party--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty enters the kitchen-- Digs around in a cabinet under sink, pulling out junk and old cleansers until-- He finds a dusty, old bottle of Jamesons, half-full-- Pou himself a tall drink--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin dresses-- Younger men, detectives, mill around him He’s tired, studies his hands, knuckles on one hand bruis scraped (will learn why next ep.)-- Looks to his belt, th RODEO BUCKLE on it dated ‘82-- At the BATHROOM MIRROR above the sink, he checks the skin beneath his chin, the thinning hairline; tries a half-ass comb-over, comb-down, fuck it-- Hart leaves the mirror, unsatisfied with it-- OVERLAP the images with first dialogue of next scene--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle, 49, twisting the flat beer-can like a doubloon--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: In eternity, where there’s no time, everything is eternal. Nothing can grow, or change. So Death created time to grow the things it would kill... And you are reborn, but into the same life you’ve always been born into. He draws a figure-eight infinity symbol around the can-me

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...-How many times have we had this conversation, Detectives? Who knows? We can never remember our lives. And we can never change anything. Your life is a surface that your consciousness traverses again and again. Forever. And that is the terrible and secret fate of all life. You're trapped. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 71 72 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 36.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like a nightmare you keep waking up into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last part of dialogue overlaps-- Hart walks in from the locker room fully dressed in suit. He approaches his desk beside Cohle, who stares ahead at a wall, thinking, hard-

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: «--You alright?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: We need to run to Abbeville today.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I gotta give a deposition, after lunch... Why?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Come on. I’1l tell you about it on the way-- They exit--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the gated entrance toward the HOLDING CELLS-- commotio Cohle and Hart face off against TWO ABBEVILLE PD DETECTIV and TWO PATROLMEN--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE A
dialogues.text: Hold on a minute, sir. You need to walk this the fuck back. You don’t barge through here--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: What happened? You assholes--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALKING down a hallway of HOLDING CELLS with PD--

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: We did take his belt. Shoelaces too. Detective. They stop at a cell where a tendril of dry, dark stain ha beneath the bars-- YELLOW CRIME SCENE TAPE over the door. stand before the cell, see--  73 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 37. Guy Francis’s body is slumped at a rear corner, bent arou post of his bunk, where a piece has been cut and bent out long time ago, making a small, hooked tooth-- Cohle stares through the bars, Francis’s wrists gouged an out, pooling at dips in the cement-- SERGEANT (CONT’D) He knew what he was looking at for the double-murder. Guess he thought about it, made a choice.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You got camera feeds?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Yes we do. They cover the hallway. Not the cells.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I want to see it.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: You wanna modify your tone, Detective? Or you wanna obtain a subpoena?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Sorry. Chief, if we could get a look, maybe get us out your hair quicker.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: ...It’s under review with our internal affairs division, but I’m sure they’d let you have a look, you ask them as nice as you did me. Cohle fumes as Hart leads him away, looking at Francis’s slumped in the cell, the dark river flowed out it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle leans past an IA INVESTIGATOR and TECHNICIAN watchi holding area’s camera footage-- FAST-FORWARDING through f of empty holding area for some time-- Francis is taken ou cell, walked out, then walked back to his cell--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Stop. What was that?

dialogues.speaker: IA INVESTIGATOR
dialogues.text: «He took a phone call at 7:15. His lawyer.  74 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 38. ON MONITOR: footage plays back, Francis returned to his c angle too steep for us to see in the cells with any depth FAST FORWARD-- Cohle watches closely as-- From a cell in a little trail of black starts flowing out--

dialogues.speaker: IA INVESTIGATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s it. Three hours of nothing... till you see the blood.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: «+.-You got audio? Sound.

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: No. Just the vid.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ...So we don’t know what somebody might’ve told him, on that phone call. We need to see your logs-- He looks between the PD men and Hart, appearing paranoid-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An abandoned GAS STATION on the prairie, convenience stor empty, gas pumps ripped out-- A DEPUTY stands with Cohle outside a PHONE BOOTH on the edge of the lot-- Cohle looks the phone over, the desolation--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ...Try to take prints. No kind of lawyer calls from here. (to deputy) Francis have relatives?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sisters, a few nieces and nephews.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: -..-Connects to his suicide?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Maybe somebody told him something. Gave him no choice... That doesn’t sound very plausible to Hart or the Deputy--  75 76 77 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart drives he and Cohle away toward the interstate-- Coh out the window, thinks-- Hart clocks that Cohle is in his obsessive thought--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You really think he could've been serious, about having something? ..-And if so, then what? Implications: Conspiracy? We got the wrong man seven year ago..?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ..-Reggie Ledoux deserved to die, Marty. That’s justice. But I’m not ruling out other agencies.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Francis and Charlie Lange both said the Yellow King. Dora Lange said Yellow King.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Why haven’t we heard anything?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: .»..You ever wonder why that task force was so hot to take the case, back in ‘95? Hart doesn’t respond, doesn’t like the gears in Cohle’s e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CID car passes again through the wilderness cut with asphalt--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 52--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: Did he mention Billy Lee Tuttle?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ..-You know that he did.  78 79 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 40.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: Tuttle died a couple years back. 2010.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Yeah. What was it? Mixed medications? So what.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: Not long after Cohle turned back up in Louisiana.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Alright. Fuck this. Fuck it right now. You tell me why you’re all over Rust. Or I walk.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: ..-His record. His reports. His stories. They don’t add up.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: So talk to him already. Stop pissing in my ear.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: We did.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You did? Huh.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: If you two talked to Rust, you didn’t get a read on him. He was getting a read on you. OFF Hart, feeling superior to his interviewers--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 42, walks through outdoor MALL with a bulky Walgree bag in hand, looking at an ad torn from the paper, pictur cell phones-- He pauses in the bustle of shoppers, looks finds the CELL PHONE STORE across the way--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart lugs the Walgreen's bag, looks at various phones on until a salesgirl, BETH (23), approaches him-- As she doe seems to be taken with something about his appearance, hi  80 81 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 41.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Can I help you with anything, sir?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Please. I’m just looking for this one... He indicates a picture from the newspaper ad; she glances him while checking the ad, lets him catch her looking--

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Right over here. I’ve been seeing that ad all day. She leads him over to the item and hands it to him--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ...It’s pretty easy to work, huh? I don’t want anything too fancy...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It’s easy... Did you want a camera? Hart thinks it over, looking at the phone box--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. Good. Beth glances at his face, his WEDDING RING, the bulky Wal bag-- NOTICE the bag is full of THREE BOXES of tampons--

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: This has one. It’s easy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Walking out the mall, looking at the phone’s box-- sees he is passing a SUBURBAN BAR-- On the bar’s TV, ESPN on-- He looks at his watch, the Walgreen’s bag--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: «Fuck it... He walks into the bar--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle sits before a computer with a small stack of thin folders-- Each one containing Missing Persons-- Notice th reports are either marked ‘made _in error’ or simply cont investigative information, their case files empty--  82 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 42. He’s copying a list of those names on his legal pad--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart sits at the bar with a beer, his second, new phone unwrapped, almost too tiny for his fingers-- He watches b and the game on TV, his Walgreen’s bag on the stool besid

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (re bag) Big weekend planned? He looks up to see Beth standing beside him--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (realizing bag) Huh? Oh. Hah. Yeah... Looking forward to it... He continues to work at the phone-- Can’t quite take his off her as she leans over the bar, orders a martini, wait

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: »..-You’re a cop, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You see my badge at check-out?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: No. Tell you the truth... I think I saw you before. Years back.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You get in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: No. You came around this place I was staying, asking about a girl...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Oh. ...My name’s Marty. She takes his hand, happy and inviting, young. We may not realize it yet, but this is the young prostitute at the ‘ whom Hart met in ep. 2--

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Beth. I like your belt buckle. You were a bullrider? He moves his bag to the floor, and she joins him, receivi drink--  83 84 85 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 43.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. SBC champs, ‘82.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I love bullriding. He grins, almost tense, drinks-- EXT. MOVING, COHLE’S TRUCK, RURAL ROAD - DAY 83 Cohle drives down a rural road, passing fields, deep fore with dread-- He sees something, slows down, almost stoppi Out the window, he sees the old BILLBOARD still stands, s ep. 1, mildewed, bleached by the sun, a GIRL’S PORTRAIT a legend: ‘10/11/87: DO YOU KNOW WHO KILLED ME? CALL 800-97

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REWARD’-- Sun has faded the girl’s face so that it’s a la void, blank-- Cohle passes it slowly, staring-- EXT. CANE FIELDS —- DAY 84 The CANE FIELDS seen in ep 1, the former Dora Lange crime scene. Cohle, 39, alone, crosses the field, toward the si OAK TREE at its center-- Cohle enters the small clearing around the oak where they found Dora Lange’s body seven years ago, sees-- The TREE hosts a SMALL ALTAR-- A half-dozen of the STICK LATTICEWORKS posted around it, a warped spiral of wood-- From a surrounding vantage, it appears the stick sculptur or something within the cane observes him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2012. ON a new CRIME SCENE FILE-- B&W, COLOR PHOTOS of th body from Lake Charles, a brief bio on the deceased ‘STEPHANIE KORDISH’-- DETAILS in pictures, in Cohle’s EYE he leafs through them-- To INVESTIGATIVE REPORT -- ‘Deceased reported missing--’ High School’-- Surface info-- It’s thin--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ...-This’s it? Really? Hell, I know this.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: What we have. So far.  86 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 44.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: Maybe you can stop dancing with us. Start talking about what you really been up to. How you spend your time. Gilbough snaps a look at Papania: too far-- Cohle closes file, phenomenonally unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I already told you how I spend my time.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: Except you been bullshitting us all day. Gilbough irritated--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: .-.’Scuse us, one more time. Gilbough rises-- Papania opens door, and both walk out, leaving Rust alone with new file and tin can men--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 FOLLOW Gilbough and Papania out the interview room, away its line of sight--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: Shouldn't have gone at him like that, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANA
dialogues.text: Maybe. Alright. But he’s been spinning our tops since he walked in. Let’s take it to real street. Their MAJOR (MARKAM, 48) meets them--

dialogues.speaker: MARKAM
dialogues.text: ...Anything? Papania and Gilbough look between one another--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: He’s not right.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: He’s not close to right. Come on. Gilbough weighs where they were against where Papania them-- left  87 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 45.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: ...We want to go for it.

dialogues.speaker: MARKAM
dialogues.text: We can’t hold him, what you got. He knows it.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: We taken this far as we can. He’s a sociopath with a thesaurus.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: ‘95 to now. He pulls it all together, doesn’t he..? He’s the missing piece. He set the guys up in ‘95. Pushed it on the two pedophiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARKAM
dialogues.text: .«+-You don’t get an admission, you blown it. He’1ll walk, maybe leave the state. The two detectives look between each other--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: .--.We’ll get it.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: Fucking right we’ll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilbough and Papania enter room-- Gilbough has a new PHOT puts down in front of Cohle--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: This’s from our crime scene. Once folks got word. ON PHOTO-- A CROWD SCENE in a rural area, all standing be

dialogues.speaker: CRIME SCENE TAPE--
dialogues.text: GILBOUGH (0.S.) (CONT’D) .+.-You recognize anybody in there? PUSH IN on photo’s faces-- Among the crowd of onlookers stands RUSTIN COHLE--

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: Lake Charles is a bit out of the way for you, huh?  "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 46.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: ..-How is it you kept her out the papers? No answer-—

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe you got friends in high places.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: Your truck and a man fitting your description were spotted in the vicinity of our scene, five times, by five different people, over the last month. Cohle’s eyes go dark, looking up at his questioners--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilbough and Papania now work Hart, 52-- Who has the CROW PHOTO that features Rust at the crime scene--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: Now, besides people seeing him and his truck around the location for weeks, you know he was off the grid, after he left in ‘02? Doesn’t show up anywhere till 2010, Louisiana. Gets his driver’s license renewed. Nobody knows what he’s been up to, meantime.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: He’s got a storage shed near Church Point. He won’t let us see what’s inside. On Hart’s face, thinking these things over, not believing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle, 49--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Fuck no you can’t look at my storage unit. Get a warrant. Christ. Try working a case.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: We're working it. How it works for us is we think, way back, you put the case on Rianne Olivier. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 47.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put it on her old boyfriend. I don’t know, maybe the Ledoux boys knew you... Maybe you traveled the same circles. Same hobbies. Maybe they had something on you. Cohle doesn’t respond, studies his accusers like prey--

dialogues.speaker: PAPANA
dialogues.text: You just kept pulling the right old murders, take the case where you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: You're a juicer. You ever black out?

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: Ever wake up, don’t remember what you did? Now Cohle rises, moves to the door--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You think you can arrest me, go ahead. You wanna follow me, go ahead. You wanna see something, get a warrant. Beyond that, thanks for the beer. Fuck off. Company men. Cohle exits the interview room, leaving the detectives stupified, furious--

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: .--Shit. Maynard. We'll keep on him. This ain’t over. Gilbough, so tightly wound, for the first time shows emot SNAPS and throws an old typewriter in a rage--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilbough and Papania make their case to Hart, 52-- He’s looking at PHOTOS of the new murder, the crowd photo--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: He bartends four days a week, this roadhouse. Has a little apartment behind it. No other accounting of his time.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: Says he drinks.  91 92 93

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ...You’re wrong. Nobody could change that much. You are dead fucking wrong.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: Hey. You been telling us, all day, about the kind of shit he’d think up. Way he’d talk. We got a good earful of that, too.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: You gonna tell me that’s a stable individual? Left a burn-out, junkie rumors. You think ten years on the sauce’s made him more reasonable? Think about this. You said it. He’d been there three months. EXT. CANE FIELDS —- DAY 48. 91 FLASHBACK from early in the first ep., Cohle and Hart bei a sheriff's deputy through the field, toward the

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .--And you two catch a heater like you never had before or since...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 52, listens--

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: One that he shines on. You saying he did such a great job. Didn’t he get you every bit of evidence? Didn't he push you where he wanted it to go?

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: He brought you Rianne Olivier.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: She wasn’t one of Ledoux’s... She was one of his. Marty’s face bleaches, staring at the new PHOTOS--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lange scene-- 92 93 FLASHBACK scene from ep. 3, Cohle and Hart with the Riann file, the photo of the girl’s back, the spiral tattoo--  94 95 96 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 49.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: --Dig in this direction... INT. COHLE’S APT - NIGHT 94 In Cohle’'s old apartment, the first time Hart saw it-- T STACKS of homicide literature--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2012, at a STORAGE FACILITY, Cohle, 49, walks a narrow co strip between rows of storage units-- He stops before a m one, looks over his shoulders, checking for tails-—-

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why can’t we see what he keeps in storage? Cohle unlocks the padlock and door-lock on the UNIT, lift metal doorway open and slips under, inside-- Closes and l from inside. A LIGHT comes on, filling the cracks around framing it in the darkness--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 52, listens, increasingly paranoid--

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: What'd he say? ‘Life is a disease’?

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: When he heard the Abbeville prisoner, Francis, knew something, he got on it. He shut it down.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: You ever thought if he made that phone call to the prisoner? Like, I dunno: the guy was trying to blackmail him...

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: He got back on it, too, didn’t he? The idea that the Lange killer was still out there? Hart pauses a few beats, sweating, taking it all in--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Yeah... Yeah, he did...

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: Looking for a new patsy, maybe.  97 98 99 100 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 50. Mutual looks as Hart sits with this--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2002. Cohle’s truck travels down the rural road leading i the desolation of PELICAN ISLAND--

dialogues.speaker: HART 2012, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: By the time I knew what Rust was doing, it was too late...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39, Cohle steps out his truck, stands before the Light of Way Academy, now even more rundown than before; seven hur seasons partially demolished the place, roofs sinking, it an overgrown tangle of jungle grass, no groundskeeping in time... Cohle holds in his hand Rianne Olivier’s OLD YEARBOOK, th stapled job-- COHLE’S MISSING PERSONS LIST is used as a bookmark, opening the yearbook onto student PHOTOS-- Rian Olivier’s picture circled in red by him-- Cohle walks toward the entrance--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle enters the darkened, moldering building. Damp, seed light through some broken windows-- Glass underfoot-- Old water stains-- Cohle walks through the dim-lit wreckage and piles of deb faded crosses and evangelical mottos on the wall. Faded acrylic cherubs with hands over eyes, ears, and mouth- se no, hear no, say no-- style looks familiar-- Cohle’s flashlight cuts through the dim. A CLASSROOM, mol generic Christian elements on the wall-- He climbs creaky, sagging steps, peeling walls, pale ligh leaking through--

dialogues.speaker: HART 2012, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Look, you’re giving me a lot to absorb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, 52, facing the other two detectives--

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: Goddamn right it’s a lot to absorb. So help us out.  101 "CH. 5: THE SECRET FATE OF ALL LIFE" - 5/12/13 51.

dialogues.speaker: GILBOUGH
dialogues.text: Whatever you can tell us. From when he got back on the Lange killer till you two had your... altercation.

dialogues.speaker: PAPANIA
dialogues.text: ...Whatever that was about. Hart bristles at something patronizing in the reference-- Still troubled by what he’s learned of Cohle, he thinks--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39, Cohle ascends the second floor of the former school-- of GLASS DISPLAY SHELVES, most fallen off, a moldering CLASSROOM-- He sweeps with his flashlight-- SEES in the beam, OLD STUDENT DESKS-- Occupying a number seats are TWIG LATTICEWORKS, some very old, cobwebbed-- The WALLS around the room are painted to look like a cypr forest beneath a purple sky with black stars-- He turns to the room’s window-- PULL BACK through broken window as MUSIC RISES, ‘ELI’ b Bosnian Rainbows-- Pulling back to the decrepit exterior school, and Cohle’s face through the broken window-- FADE TO BLACK.
